article.title: A no-short scalar hair theorem for rotating Kerr black holes

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the "no-short hair" relation (r<sub>field</sub> > r<sub>null</sub>) indicate about hairy black holes?
choices: The external matter fields of a hairy black hole must extend beyond the event horizon.
The event horizon of a hairy black hole is smaller than that of a non-hairy black hole with the same mass.
The external matter fields of a hairy black hole must extend beyond the null circular geodesic of the spacetime.
Hairy black holes cannot exist in static, spherically symmetric spacetimes.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does this equation describe in the context of Kerr black holes and massive scalar fields? ω<sub>field</sub> = ω<sub>c</sub> = mΩ<sub>H</sub>
choices: The frequency of Hawking radiation emitted by the black hole.
The threshold frequency for superradiant amplification of bosonic fields in the Kerr black hole spacetime.
The angular velocity of the event horizon of the Kerr black hole.
The mass of the scalar field required to form a bound state with the Kerr black hole.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the function V(y) represent in the context of the radial Teukolsky equation?
choices: The scalar field strength at a given point in space.
The effective radial potential experienced by the linearized massive scalar field.
The angular momentum of the scalar field.
The energy density of the scalar field.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of this inequality in the context of stationary bound-state Kerr scalar clouds? r<sub>max</sub> > r<sub>+</sub>²/r<sub>-</sub>
choices: It establishes an upper bound on the peak location of the scalar cloud.
It demonstrates that the scalar cloud is confined within the event horizon.
It provides a universal lower bound on the peak location of the scalar cloud, independent of the specific properties of the scalar field.
It proves that scalar clouds can only exist for specific values of the black hole\'s angular momentum.
